attributes.comment:
I would like to recommend that the I-600 fees for international adoption be held
at their current levels, even if the fees for other types of petitions are
raised. Another alternative would be to increase the amount of time the
documents for an international adoption are valid from 18 months to at least 24
months (and preferably 30 months). Yet another alternative would be to offer a
substantially lower fee to update the documents if they are nearing expiration
and the adoption has not yet been completed.

A large fraction of international adoptions can not be completed within the
specified 18 month window, therefore these families must re-apply and pay the
full fees a second time. Thus the USCIS receives 2x the fees from most adoptive
families as compared with other petitioners. Adoptive families generally have
no control over the speed of their process once the paperwork has been sent to
the country, so there is nothing they can do to avoid being double charged.

I am currently starting the process to adopt a child from China. The current
wait time once the paperwork is submitted is more than 18 months, and it is
getting longer. I just received my I-171H and I expect it to take 1-2 months
before the papers will be officially registered in China. So the wait from
I-171H to child will be at least 20 months. So I know I will be required to pay
the USCIS fees again even though there is nothing I can do to speed up this
process (and I would speed it up in a heartbeat if I could!!).

Thank you for your consideration,

Laura Kramer
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Laura Kramer
